hotspots.label: Ocean Wave Energy
hotspots.fact: The big wave crashing against the rocks is full of energy from the ocean! This is called **kinetic energy** — that's the energy of motion. When waves hit rocks, they transfer that energy, which can move sand, break rocks apart over time, and change the shape of the beach.

vocabulary.definition: The energy that something has when it is moving or in motion.

hotspots.label: Dark Rocks
hotspots.fact: These dark rocks are made of solid matter with specific **physical properties** like color, shape, and hardness. Over many years, waves crashing against these rocks with great force cause **weathering** — the rocks slowly break down into smaller pieces and sand grains that you see on the beach.

vocabulary.definition: The slow breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces by wind, water, and ice.

hotspots.label: Sandy Beach
hotspots.fact: The sand on this beach is mostly tiny, broken pieces of rock! Through the **force** of waves pushing and pulling, sand gets moved along the shore in a process called **erosion**. The same forces that break rocks also shape and reshape beaches every single day.

vocabulary.definition: The wearing away and movement of rocks and soil by wind, water, or ice.

hotspots.label: Wave Spray & Water
hotspots.fact: When waves crash on rocks, the impact creates water spray that flies through the air! This happens because the water is in **motion** — moving fast with a lot of **force**. The force of the moving water is so powerful that it can change the landscape and move heavy rocks over time.

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull that can make something move, stop, or change direction.
